options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Similarity theorem

options.label: D
options.text: Scaling theorem

options.label: A

options.text: The sum of the areas of the two smaller blobs is less than the area of the larger blob.

options.label: C
options.text: The sum of the areas of the two smaller blobs is equal to the area of the larger blob.

options.label: D
options.text: The areas of the three blobs are not related.

options.text: They require too many volunteers

options.label: C
options.text: They cannot establish causal relationships between substances and their effects on health

options.label: D
options.text: They are not rigorous enough

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of randomization in a randomized clinical trial?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the study groups are of equal size

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that the study groups are representative of the population

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure that the only difference between the groups is the one being studied

options.label: D
options.text: To ensure that the study is blinded

multiple-choice.question: What is a confounding variable in an epidemiological study?

options.label: A
options.text: A factor that is being studied

options.label: B
options.text: A factor that can affect results, in addition to the factor being studied

options.label: C
options.text: A factor that is not relevant to the study

options.label: D
options.text: A factor that is only relevant to one of the study groups

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to consider the limitations of a study before jumping to conclusions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because studies are always flawed

options.label: B
options.text: Because studies are never reliable

options.label: C
options.text: Because studies can have inherent flaws and limitations that affect their results

options.label: D
options.text: Because studies are always biased
